cusip_vs_ticker.title: CUSIP vs Ticker Symbol
cusip_vs_ticker.description: CUSIP numbers and ticker symbols are different identifiers for securities. Understanding the difference is crucial for trading and research.
examples: CUSIP: 9-character alphanumeric code (e.g., 037833100 for Apple Inc.)
Ticker: Short symbol used for trading (e.g., AAPL for Apple Inc.)
CUSIPs are used for settlement and record-keeping, not trading
Use ticker symbols when searching for stock prices or placing trades
Every security has a unique CUSIP, but only publicly traded ones have tickers
cusip_vs_ticker.correction_template: It looks like you're using a CUSIP number. For dividend and stock information, please use the ticker symbol instead. For example, use 'AAPL' instead of the CUSIP '037833100'.

distribution_vs_dividend.title: Distribution vs Dividend - Tax Implications
distribution_vs_dividend.description: Distributions and dividends have important differences, especially regarding tax treatment. Understanding these can help optimize your passive income strategy.
examples: Qualified Dividends: From C-corps, taxed at favorable 0-20% rates
Ordinary Dividends: Taxed at ordinary income rates (up to 37%)
ROC (Return of Capital): Not immediately taxable, reduces cost basis
REIT Distributions: Often mostly ordinary income, may include ROC
MLP Distributions: Complex tax treatment with K-1 forms
Tracking cost basis is critical for distributions with ROC components
distribution_vs_dividend.correction_template: Note: REITs and MLPs pay distributions, not dividends. Distributions often include Return of Capital (ROC), which has different tax treatment than qualified dividends.

dividend_yield_misconception.title: High Yield Isn't Always Better
dividend_yield_misconception.description: A very high dividend yield can be a warning sign rather than an opportunity. Understanding yield sustainability is crucial.
examples: Extremely high yields (>10%) may indicate a recent price drop
Price drops often signal dividend cut risk
Check payout ratio - above 80% is concerning for most stocks
Look at dividend growth history, not just current yield
Sustainable 3-6% yields often beat unsustainable 10%+ yields long-term
dividend_yield_misconception.correction_template: While high yields are attractive, yields above 8-10% often indicate elevated risk. Consider payout ratio, dividend history, and company fundamentals.

reinvestment_misconception.title: DRIP vs Manual Reinvestment
reinvestment_misconception.description: Dividend Reinvestment Plans (DRIPs) and manual reinvestment have different advantages and tax implications.
examples: DRIPs: Automatic reinvestment, often with no fees
DRIPs may allow fractional share purchases
All dividends are taxable even if reinvested
Manual reinvestment gives more control over timing and allocation
DRIPs can complicate cost basis tracking
Consider tax-advantaged accounts for automatic reinvestment
reinvestment_misconception.correction_template: Remember: Reinvested dividends are still taxable in the year received, whether through DRIP or manual reinvestment.

ex_dividend_date_confusion.title: Ex-Dividend Date Timing
ex_dividend_date_confusion.description: Understanding ex-dividend dates is crucial for dividend capture strategies and avoiding disappointment.
examples: Must own stock BEFORE ex-dividend date to receive dividend
Stock price typically drops by dividend amount on ex-date
Declaration date ≠ Ex-date ≠ Record date ≠ Payment date
T+1 settlement: Buy at least 1 day before ex-date
Dividend capture rarely works due to price adjustment
Focus on long-term holding, not short-term dividend capture
ex_dividend_date_confusion.correction_template: To receive the upcoming dividend, you must purchase shares before the ex-dividend date. The stock price will adjust down on the ex-date.

payout_ratio_misunderstanding.title: Payout Ratio Guidelines
payout_ratio_misunderstanding.description: Payout ratio indicates dividend sustainability and varies by sector and company maturity.
examples: Payout Ratio = Dividends / Earnings
0-40%: Conservative, room for growth
40-60%: Balanced, sustainable for most companies
60-80%: High, limited growth potential
80%+: Risky, potential dividend cut ahead
REITs: Must pay 90%+ of taxable income, so high ratios are normal
MLPs: Use distributable cash flow, not earnings
payout_ratio_misunderstanding.correction_template: Payout ratios above 80% suggest limited dividend safety buffer. For REITs, evaluate based on FFO (Funds From Operations) instead of earnings.

dividend_safety: Review dividend growth history (5+ years of increases is positive)
Monitor debt levels and interest coverage
Diversify across sectors and payment months
tax_optimization: Hold qualified dividend stocks in taxable accounts
Keep REITs and high-yield bonds in tax-advantaged accounts
Consider tax-loss harvesting to offset dividend income
Track cost basis carefully, especially with DRIPs
Understand your state's tax treatment of dividends
portfolio_building: Aim for monthly dividend income through strategic timing
Don't chase yields above 8% without thorough research

key_terms.Dividend Aristocrat: S&P 500 company with 25+ years of consecutive dividend increases
key_terms.Dividend King: Company with 50+ years of consecutive dividend increases
key_terms.Dividend Champion: Company with 25+ years of dividend growth (any index)
key_terms.DRIP: Dividend Reinvestment Plan - automatic dividend reinvestment
key_terms.Qualified Dividend: Dividend eligible for favorable long-term capital gains tax rates
key_terms.Payout Ratio: Percentage of earnings paid as dividends
key_terms.Yield on Cost: Current annual dividend / original purchase price
key_terms.FFO: Funds From Operations - key REIT profitability metric
key_terms.Distribution: Payment from REITs, MLPs, or funds (may include ROC)
